title: Intense video takes you inside the cockpit of a C-17 Globemaster as it flies by skyscrapers in Australia
text:
An Australian air force C-17A Globemaster cargo plane and F/A-18 fighters zipped through Brisbane this month ahead of an airshow.

Footage shows the crew of the C-17A flying close to Brisbane's skyscrapers as warnings chime in the cockpit.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

"Holy s---," pretty much sums up my reaction to the recent footage of Royal Australian Air Force pilots zooming past skyscrapers in a C-17A Globemaster as the words "terrain, terrain, terrain," and "obstacle ahead" blare over the intercom in the cockpit.

The 360-degree cockpit footage was posted to the Royal Australian Air Force's official YouTube page on Friday along with a series of impressive photos showing the not-so-lumbering beast of a plane flying over (like, just barely over) Brisbane, Australia ahead of an airshow this weekend.

Yes, that video was just a rehearsal.

This impressive clip isn't the only footage of the flight.

A similar video, posted to Instagram by 9News reporter Rob Morrison with offered a glimpse from the other side of the cockpit — you know, the one nearest to the buildings. (Click to the right on the Instagram post for Morrison's video.)

Riding with the RAAF boys. . . . . #terrainterrain #obstacleahead #raaf #c17 #globemaster #brisbane #riverfire @nathanat9 @9newsqueensland A post shared by Rob Morrison (@rob__morrison) on Sep 27, 2019 at 7:35pm PDT Sep 27, 2019 at 7:35pm PDT

Despite the size of the C-17, it certainly can move.

As The War Zone's Tyler Rogoway noted in a recent post, the RAAF frequently puts its heavy transport planes through their paces during similar low-flying training missions and public performances.

A No. 36 Squadron C-17A Globemaster low over the Brisbane River for Sunsuper Riverfire 2019. Royal Australian Air Force/Facebook

"The C-17A will conduct passes over the Brisbane River and the [Central Business District] as the pilots expertly maneuver the aircraft as part of the preparation for Riverfire display," the RAAF said in a statement, referring to this past weekend's Sunsuper Riverfire and flight demonstration, which included flyovers from some Super Hornets as well.

"Each flying display is planned and flown beforehand and the pilots train to a high skill level to perform such maneuver," the statement continues. "The aircraft will be at least 100 meters clear of terrain or any buildings during the display. The flying display will provide the public a great opportunity to take photos of the aircraft."

A No. 1 Squadron F/A-18F Super Hornet over Brisbane for Sunsuper Riverfire 2019 while crowds on apartment balconies look on. Royal Australian Air Force/Facebook

That's certainly true. The photos published to the official RAAF Facebook page of Aussie aircraft buzzing buildings are impressive enough to put Maverick to shame:
description: An Australian C-17 rehearsed low-level flying through Brisbane as the warnings "terrain, terrain, terrain" and "obstacle ahead" blared in the cockpit.
